ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A strong focus on political theory compared to Fall H&P; most discussions can be extrapolated fairly easily into contemporary politics.

This course provided me with a solid background in European political thought. Professor Renaud takes care not to give an uncritical presentation of this canon, yet at the same time explains the relevance and importance of the texts we read. My paper writing skills improved immensely.

I learned to closely examine texts and evaluate their influences on our world today.  I was able to delve deep into the fine details of each argument and explore the political and historical consequences of every thinker's work.
Reading, analysis, and comparison of works of political theory. Writing in short papers.
An overview of fundamental texts in western political philosophy. Ability to analyze difficult texts and convey thoughts on them through writing.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really enjoyed the course!  The readings offered such fascinating glimpses into history and politics from many of the thinkers I've always heard about in previous history classes but never had the chance to read.  I've left the class with a much better understanding of the works and how they continue to bear relevance in our world today.

The readings in DRST 006 are more dynamic, relevant, and fun than their predecessors in DRST 005. On the syllabus, The Federalist Papers, while understandable after the social contract theorists, felt irrelevant and unnecessary and could be removed. Correspondingly, both the Arendt and the Dubois readings would have benefited from a third seminar.
Prof. Renaud is great. He has many insightful opinions on the course topics and is also good at leading discussion. The level of workload is appropriate. Cant think of any specific weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think having a small group was particularly important, as was having plenty of structure in the discussion.
The virtual seminars were all highly engaging--I looked forward to class each week!
Virtual seminar was smooth and satisfying. My instructor used Zoom's integrated "Raise Hand" function, which I think is an improvement over raised hands in-person.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! And do take it with Professor Renaud; he's amazing.

Yes!  H&P is an amazing experience--you get to take the great canonical works off their pedestals and truly examine them for what they are.  It's a chance to broaden your thinking in ways you never knew were possible and place the works of so many great thinkers in conversation with each other.
Yes. I was reluctant to continue with DS after the first semester. This class was an improvement and I'm glad I stayed. It was also satisfying to finish reading through the DS canon.
Yes! H&P with Prof. Renaud has been a highlight of my semester. I strongly recommend students who are interested in history of political thought to take a class with him.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual seminars, along with a weekly lecture
